questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of productive cough, swelling of the legs and feet, and fatigue. He has had progressive dyspnea on exertion for the past 2 months. Twelve years ago, he received a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation. He has coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include aspirin, simvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale. He is 179 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 127 kg (279.9 lb); BMI is 41 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. Bilateral basilar rales are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced apical heartbeat. A grade 3/6, crescendo-decrescendo diastolic murmur is heard over the apex. There is bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with prosthetic valves are at increased risk of developing infective endocarditis (IE), especially subacute IE, which can manifest with a heart murmur. IE may lead to CHF over a span of days to weeks. Although this patient has a murmur and signs of CHF, he does not have a fever nor any other Duke criteria, making IE unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with dyspnea and chronic productive cough (≥ 3 months in 2 consecutive years) and may lead to tachypnea, cyanosis, and pulmonary hypertension in later stages. Physical examination typically shows wheezing and a prolonged expiratory phase. Although this patient has a cough and a positive smoking history, he has only had a cough for 3 weeks and no obstruction on lung auscultation, making COPD unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Typical pneumonia manifests with a sudden onset of malaise, fever, productive cough, and crackles and bronchial breath sounds on auscultation. Atypical pneumonia, on the other hand, manifests with a gradual onset of unproductive cough, dyspnea, extrapulmonary manifestations, and often unremarkable findings on pulmonary examination. Although this patient presents with a productive cough, he has no fever and his pulmonary examination shows bilateral basilar rales, both of which are indicative of CHF rather than pneumonia.

D) CORRECT:

The patient underwent a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation 12 years ago. Biological valves (both bovine and porcine) typically have a short lifespan due to sclerotic degeneration. If the prosthetic valve becomes dysfunctional, the patient may have to undergo open-heart surgery for valve replacement again. Possible complications of the biological prosthetic valve include obstruction/stenosis, as seen in this patient, and regurgitation, both of which may manifest with signs of CHF.

Biological prosthetic valves are preferred over mechanical prosthetic valves in patients > 65 years of age because the degeneration process is slower than in younger patients and they typically do not need further surgery to replace the valve again. In addition, anticoagulation is only needed for 3 months following the surgery. Thus, biologic prosthetic valves are also preferred in patients with a high risk of bleeding, and in women with a desire to have children, since certain anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are teratogenic.
Image Description:

A stented bioprosthetic valve, consisting of xenograft material (most commonly porcine aortic valve leaflets or bovine pericardium) mounted on a manufactured supporting stent.

E) INCORRECT:

The clinical presentation of pulmonary embolism (PE) is variable. Patients can present with chest pain, coughing, dyspnea, tachycardia, or even cardiogenic shock. Risk factors include immobility, inherited hypercoagulability disorders, pregnancy, and recent surgery. This patient presents with coughing and dyspnea, which may mimic PE. However, the patient does not have a history of recent immobilization. Furthermore, he has mitral valve stenosis and bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles, which makes CHF more likely than pulmonary embolism.
questions.hint: This patient's cough, swelling of the lower extremities, fatigue, progressive dyspnea on exertion, and pitting edema in addition to bilateral basilar rales (suggestive of pulmonary edema) and a laterally displaced apical heartbeat (suggestive of an enlarged heart), are consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine medical check-up. The patient feels well. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recurrent panic attacks. He had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He underwent a left inguinal hernia repair at the age of 25 years. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. He works as a nurse at a local hospital. He is married and has two children. His father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70 years. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit following his myocardial infarction. He drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, fluoxetine, metformin, and a multivitamin. He appears well-nourished. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is best heard at the apex. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing murmur during diastole heard best at the 2nd left intercostal space. The location of the murmur at the apex and the occurrence during systole make this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble and a loud S1 heard best at the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble heard best at the lower parasternal region. This patient has a systolic heart murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that may radiate to the axilla and is best heard at the apex. While the location and the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest mitral regurgitation, the timing (mid-to-late systole) makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur heard best at the lower parasternal region. While the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest tricuspid regurgitation, the character, point of maximum intensity, and timing make this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is best heard at the left sternal border or the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, suggesting a different answer option.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

G) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis manifests as a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is typically heard best at the right upper sternal border, not at the apex.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis primarily manifests during early childhood as a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2nd left intercostal space. In adults, it may result from carcinoid syndrome or chronic rheumatic fever. The location of the murmur at the apex suggests another diagnosis.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

I) CORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in the US and is usually asymptomatic, as in this patient. It typically manifests as a high-frequency, midsystolic click combined with a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur heard best at the apex, which is consistent with this patient's auscultatory findings. Mitral valve prolapse is most often idiopathic, but can also be secondary to conditions such as rheumatic heart disease, infectious endocarditis, connective tissue disorders, or myocardial infarction (MI). Following MI, ischemia of the papillary muscles and subsequent rupture of the chordae tendinae may cause one or both mitral valve leaflets to prolapse into the left atrium, which leads to acute symptoms of regurgitation. Even though this patient has a history of MI, his asymptomatic presentation 3 years later suggests an idiopathic etiology.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: This type of murmur will typically occur earlier during systole and with increased intensity when the patient abruptly stands up from a squatting position or performs the Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of difficulty breathing. He has had recurrent palpitations over the past 2 years. During this time, he has also had several episodes of anxiety despite no change in his daily life. He has occasional sharp chest pain localized to the left upper sternal border. He has no abdominal pain or leg swelling. Two years ago, he had streptococcal pharyngitis, which was promptly treated with a 10-day course of penicillin. He has never traveled outside of the country. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3/6 holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex and radiates to the axilla with a mid-systolic click. Bilateral fine crackles are heard on lung auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ectopic production of serotonin occurs in carcinoid syndrome. In extraintestinal carcinoid tumors and carcinoid tumors that have metastasized to the liver, increased serotonin that bypasses hepatic first-pass metabolism and enters the right heart can lead to fibrotic degeneration of valves and, as a result, pulmonary valve or tricuspid valve disease (i.e., carcinoid heart disease). The left side of the heart (including the mitral valve) is very rarely affected because serotonin is broken down by pulmonary enzymes before entering the left atrium. This patient's murmur is best heard at the apex, which is not consistent with murmurs heard in right-sided valvular disease. Moreover, this patient lacks classic findings of carcinoid syndrome such as flushing, recurrent diarrhea, telangiectasia, and asthmatic wheezing.

B) CORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is caused by the accumulation of dermatan sulfate within the connective tissue of the mitral valve. In developed countries, it is the most common cause of mitral valve degeneration and subsequent mitral valve prolapse. As the disease course progresses, mitral regurgitation can occur. This patient presents with common features of mitral valve prolapse (palpitations, anxiety, chest pain, mid-systolic click). The new-onset dyspnea, holosystolic murmur, and crackles on lung auscultation are consistent with regurgitation of the mitral valve, indicating an advanced disease process.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification is a common degenerative process involving the mitral annulus that can, depending on the severity of calcification, result in mitral stenosis and/or regurgitation. However, in most cases, calcific valve degeneration is asymptomatic and only has a negligible influence on mitral valve function. It is the most common cause of aortic valve stenosis, not mitral valve regurgitation. Patients with aortic stenosis may present with exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris-like symptoms, and a systolic murmur. However, aortic valve stenosis often also manifests with exertional dizziness or syncope and causes a late systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates bilaterally to the carotids, not a holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the apex.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory valve degeneration occurs in rheumatic heart disease, a late sequela of group A streptococcal infection, which often affects the mitral valve. Earlier stages of rheumatic heart disease most often involve mitral valve regurgitation, which then later develops into mitral stenosis. The pathogenesis of the disease involves cross-reactivity with group A streptococci (also referred to as molecular mimicry), which results in the development of autoimmune antibodies. While this patient has a history of streptococcal pharyngitis, he was adequately treated with penicillin, which makes rheumatic heart disease unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive catecholamine release is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma. While patients with pheochromocytoma often have bouts of intense palpitations and elevated blood pressure, other common symptoms include pallor, throbbing headache, diaphoresis, and hypertensive crisis, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, pheochromocytoma would not account for this patient's dyspnea and holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla, and bilateral lung crackles on auscultation raise suspicion of pulmonary edema due to acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of shortness of breath while lying on her back over the past month. During this period, she has also had several episodes of bloody coughing. The patient reports that she had a heart problem when she was a child that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated to the US from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows tachycardia and no P waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation may be caused by pulmonary hypertension as a result of volume overload in patients with left-sided heart failure. Such patients would present with signs of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which would explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. However, pulmonary regurgitation causes a diastolic murmur heard best at the second left intercostal space parasternally (sometimes referred to as Graham Steel murmur), which would be more pronounced during inspiration.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a high-frequency mid-to-late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it manifests as a holosystolic murmur (i.e., audible between S1 and S2) best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2).
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2) at the fifth left intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral valve stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and increased pulmonary wedge pressure) and a backup of blood into the lungs. Volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explains this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. The absence of P waves confirms atrial fibrillation, a common complication of mitral stenosis. This patient most likely suffered from rheumatic fever, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

H) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is best heard as a systolic murmur at the fourth intercostal space parallel to the sternum and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

I) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may lead to signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient would likely show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 months. The dyspnea occurs on moderate exertion and during the night; he sometimes wakes up coughing and “gasping for air.” He has also had several episodes of heart pounding. Two weeks ago, he had a runny nose and a productive cough. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. He has never smoked. He drinks one to two beers occasionally. He has a history of intravenous illicit drug use but has not used in over 25 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral basilar rales. Cardiac auscultation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) as the cause of his LHF. MR typically manifests with a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex. Mitral murmurs are heard best during expiration and while the patient lies on the left side. Causes of primary MR include degenerative mitral valve disease (mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae), infective endocarditis, and rheumatic fever.
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with some features of pericarditis including fatigue, palpitations, and exertional dyspnea, which are often preceded by flu-like symptoms. But he lacks other typical findings, such as fever, and sharp, pleuritic chest pain, and does not have a high-pitched scratching sound (pericardial friction rub) on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve regurgitation (TR) manifests with a holosystolic murmur and can occur as a result of infective endocarditis in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. However, the murmur of TR is heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of TR is intensified during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur is intensified on expiration. Moreover, TR is extremely rare and would typically manifest with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis (PS) primarily manifests during early childhood with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2nd left ICS. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of PS is intensified during deep inspiration rather than during expiration as in this patient. Moreover, PS is rare and would typically present with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

E) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic valve regurgitation, this condition would manifest with a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th ICSs and along the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by mitral valve stenosis (MS) and mitral murmurs are heard best at the apex, MS would manifest with a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble, and loud S1.
Image Description:

Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the mitral valve to completely open during diastole, impeding blood from flowing from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole. This generates a low-frequency mid-diastolic murmur that is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex and is often accompanied by a loud S1. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

G) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic stenosis, this condition would manifest with a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd ICS at the right upper sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.
questions.hint: This patient presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and features of pulmonary congestion (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar rales on auscultation). In combination with a heart murmur, these findings are highly suggestive of left-sided heart failure (LHF) caused by valvular heart disease. The auscultation findings reveal a systolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left intercostal space (ICS), the area of the cardiac apex.

questions.text:
An otherwise healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations. He says that he can feel his heartbeat in his chest all the time. For the past 3 weeks, he has had shortness of breath on exertion. He has not had chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at the age of 25 years. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (PS) is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare but can occur in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. It typically manifests with features of right-sided heart failure rather than the dyspnea and palpitations seen in this patient. The typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, which is heard best parasternally at the left 2nd intercostal space, often with a widely split S2. This patient's diastolic murmur rules out PS as a possible diagnosis.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

C) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies. Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Timing the murmur against the carotid pulse is an important skill to master; if you are finding it difficult to time the murmur, try listening to the murmur again between 10 and 20 seconds using a slow playback speed and gradually increase the playback speed until you are proficient in timing the murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can present with palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is one of the most common valvular abnormalities in the US, especially in young women. However, a widened pulse pressure is not common in MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings of MVP would include a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left midclavicular line of the 5th intercostal space).
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: The peak of the carotid pulse upstroke occurs immediately after S1. In this patient, there is a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse upstroke, which is consistent with a diastolic timing. With early diastolic murmurs, the S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation, as is the case here.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation. Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of aortic regurgitation in resource-limited countries.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man comes to the physician because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can also present with exertional dyspnea. However, auscultation of an MVP shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is usually asymptomatic but can also manifest as exertional dyspnea. However, features of right-sided heart failure would be present, and auscultation in PR would show an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard parasternally in the left 2nd ICS.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is extremely rare and typically presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the typical murmur of TS is a soft mid-diastolic murmur heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.

H) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

I) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He feels well. His pulse is 80/min and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a holosystolic murmur in the 4th intercostal space along the left sternal border that gets louder during inspiration. The increase of this patient's murmur is best explained by which of the following hemodynamic changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased peripheral vascular resistance (afterload) does not occur during inspiration. Asking a patient to squat can effectively increase afterload, though. Increased afterload leads to enhanced murmur intensity in mitral regurgitation, aortic regurgitation, and ventricular septal defect. In all these instances, increased afterload augments the pathological, retrograde blood flow across the mitral valve, aortic valve, or ventricular septal defect, respectively. Increased blood flow is appreciated as a more intense murmur.

B) CORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur in the 4th intercostal space along the left sternal border that gets louder during inspiration is classic for tricuspid regurgitation. Tricuspid regurgitation, unlike other holosystolic murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation or ventricular septal defects), increases during inspiration. Inspiration causes a period of negative intrathoracic pressure, allowing for increased venous return to the heart, ultimately producing increased right ventricular stroke volume. This excess blood volume must be entirely ejected through the tricuspid valve, producing the increased intensity of the murmur. The left ventricle stroke volume is affected in the opposite manner with inspiration decreasing venous return from the pulmonary veins, leading to a reduction in left ventricular stroke volume. Consequently, the left-sided holosystolic murmurs of mitral regurgitation and ventricular septal defects do not augment with inspiration.

As a diagnostic maneuver, inspiration increases the intensity of all murmurs involving the right side of the heart. These also include diastolic murmurs like tricuspid stenosis and pulmonary regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

During inspiration, the intrathoracic pressure is negative. This reduces the barometric compressive force on the outer surface of the pulmonary vessels, permitting an increase in the vessel capacitance. This increase in vessel capacity is part of the explanation for the augmented murmur intensity during inspiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular venous return occurs during inspiration but does not impact right-sided heart murmurs such as tricuspid regurgitation. Left-sided murmur intensity, such as in mitral regurgitation, is typically unaffected or minimally reduced by this phenomenon.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased systemic venous compliance, such as immediately following a change from supine to standing, leads to decreased preload as a result of blood pooling in the peripheral venous circulation. The majority of cardiac murmurs become softer in this scenario as a result of diminished blood flow across valves. The one notable exception is the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which increases. Altered systemic venous compliance does not have a role in explaining this patient's examination findings.
questions.hint: A holosystolic murmur that becomes louder on inspiration hints at a right-sided murmur. The auscultation site suggests tricuspid valve regurgitation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because she has noticed that he sometimes has difficulty breathing when he is playing outside. He is also easily fatigued by exertion. He has been otherwise healthy and appears well. Cardiac examination shows a regular rate and rhythm with wide splitting of S2. The lungs are clear to auscultation. This patient is most likely to have a systolic murmur best auscultated at which of the following labeled locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Point A corresponds to the right carotid artery. Auscultatory findings here can include bruits (from stenosis or external compression) or radiation from the systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur of aortic stenosis. Neither of these lesions would be likely to account for easy fatigability or a wide-split S2 in a pediatric patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Point B corresponds to the left carotid artery. Auscultatory findings here can include bruits (from stenosis or external compression) or radiation from the systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur of aortic stenosis. Neither of these lesions would be likely to account for fatigability or a wide-split S2 in a pediatric patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Point C, which corresponds to the second right intercostal space at the right sternal border, is the best auscultation site for aortic stenosis, which is associated with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur. Although anomalies of the aortic valve (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve) are among the most common congenital heart defects, clinically apparent aortic stenosis would be unlikely in a 5-year-old patient. Moreover, in aortic stenosis, a paradoxical split of S2 would be expected on cardiac auscultation rather than a wide splitting of S2.

D) CORRECT:

Point D, which corresponds to the second left intercostal space at the parasternal border, is the best auscultation site for pulmonary stenosis. This 5-year-old boy presents with episodic dyspnea, easy fatigability, and a widely split S2, which should raise concern for a congenital valvular issue. Clear lung auscultation indicates an anomaly that is likely right-sided. Pulmonary stenosis causes an outflow obstruction from the right ventricle, which will cause delayed closing of the pulmonic valve (split S2) and a systolic ejection murmur. Flow murmurs and the murmur of ASD can also be auscultated at this site.

Wide splitting of S2 can also be a sign of right bundle branch block, pulmonary hypertension, and right ventricular volume overload (e.g., due to an atrial septal defect).
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

E) INCORRECT:

Point E corresponds to the right axilla. Unless the patient has dextrocardia, a cardiac murmur would not be expected at this site.

F) INCORRECT:

Point F corresponds to the right 5th intercostal space at the parasternal line. Unless the patient has dextrocardia, a cardiac murmur would not be expected at this site.

G) INCORRECT:

Point G, which corresponds to the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line, is the best auscultation site for murmurs originating from the mitral valve. A diastolic murmur would be expected in mitral stenosis, a systolic murmur in mitral valve prolapse, and a holosystolic murmur in mitral regurgitation. Severe mitral regurgitation can cause wide splitting of S2, which is seen in this patient. However, severe mitral regurgitation would classically manifest with signs of left-sided heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, dyspnea, cough), which this patient does not have.

H) INCORRECT:

Point H corresponds to the left axilla. The high-pitched, blowing, holosystolic murmur of mitral regurgitation can be auscultated at this site. Severe mitral regurgitation can cause wide splitting of S2, which is seen in this patient. However, severe mitral regurgitation would classically manifest with signs of left-sided heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, dyspnea, cough), which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: This patient's widely split S2 suggests delayed right ventricle emptying (e.g., from pulmonary valve stenosis).

questions.text: A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with fatigue and bilateral leg swelling. Her pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Her abdomen is distended with shifting dullness and tender hepatomegaly is present. Cardiovascular examination shows a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that increases in intensity with inspiration. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 45,XO genotype causes Turner syndrome. The most common cardiovascular abnormalities in Turner syndrome are bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and aortic dissection. Chronic and/or severe aortic valve disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. However, this patient presents with features of right heart failure. Left heart murmurs do not increase on inspiration, unlike the auscultatory findings in this patient. Moreover, other typical manifestations of Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, amenorrhea) are absent in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Acquired tricuspid valve regurgitation and signs of right-sided heart failure in a previously healthy patient suggest a diagnosis of tricuspid valve endocarditis, for which intravenous drug use (IVDU) is the strongest predisposing factor. The most commonly isolated pathogens in infective endocarditis due to IVDU are Staphylococcus aureus (most common), streptococci, and enterococci.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin B1 deficiency (usually secondary to alcohol use disorder in developed countries) results in wet beriberi, which typically manifests with high-output cardiac failure. While jugular venous distention, ascites, and peripheral edema are commonly seen in patients with high-output cardiac failure, other features such as dyspnea, tachypnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bounding peripheral pulses, a midsystolic murmur, and an S3 gallop would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Defects in the fibrillin gene are responsible for Marfan syndrome. The most common cardiovascular structures involved in Marfan syndrome are the aorta and valves of the left heart (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse). Chronic and/or severe left valvular heart disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. However, this patient presents with features of right heart failure. Left heart murmurs (except for mitral valve prolapse) do not increase on inspiration, unlike the murmur in this patient. Moreover, other typical features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., joint hypermobility, lens subluxation) are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Untreated group A streptococcus pharyngitis can lead to rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which can manifest with heart failure in young or middle-aged individuals. However, as RHD mainly affects the valves of the left heart (i.e., the mitral and/or aortic valves), features of left heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bilateral basilar rales) would be expected and the intensity of the murmur would not increase on inspiration.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of right heart failure (jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly) and a murmur consistent with tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and nocturnal cough for the past 2 weeks. On two occasions, his cough was bloody. He had a heart condition as a child that was treated with antibiotics. He emigrated to the US from Kazakhstan 15 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a mid-systolic high-frequency click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, but this is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur at the fifth intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and ↑ PCWP) and a backup of blood into the lungs. The volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. This patient most likely had rheumatic fever as a child, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it presents as a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient could show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is hospitalized with acute respiratory failure after being intubated by emergency medical technicians. Her initial symptoms were acute left-sided chest pain, shortness of breath, and dizziness.
Two years ago, she received a bileaflet mechanical mitral valve after developing native mitral-valve endocarditis. She subsequently developed chronic atrial fibrillation, for which she also takes warfarin. In addition, she takes valsartan, atenolol, and a low-dose oral contraceptive pill.
On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C, her heart rate is 130 beats per minute and irregularly irregular, her blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 94% on 60% inspired oxygen.
She has jugular venous distention and coarse crackles in both lung fields without wheezing or stridor. She has a faint mechanical first heart sound, a narrowly split second heart sound, and a 3/6 holosystolic murmur and a 2/4 diastolic rumble (both loudest at the apex).
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals pulmonary edema. An electrocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response but without acute ST-segment or T-wave changes.
Laboratory testing documents an international normalized ratio of 1.4.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of acute aortic insufficiency may be difficult to make on physical examination; rapid equalization between left ventricular diastolic pressure and systemic diastolic pressure shortens and softens the diastolic murmur, which is typically heard at the left sternal border. In acute aortic insufficiency, there may be a systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border due to increased flow across the aortic valve, but this is usually a soft murmur. This patient has both holosystolic and diastolic murmurs, heard best at the apex, suggesting mitral-valve pathology.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive use increases the risk for thromboembolism, but pulmonary embolism is a less likely cause of this patient’s decompensation, given the cardiac auscultatory findings (a reduced mechanical first heart sound and systolic/diastolic murmurs in the mitral position).

C) INCORRECT:

Paravalvular abscess is a less likely cause of the acute decompensation, given the absence of preceding symptoms of endocarditis; in addition, it would not cause a reduced mechanical first heart sound.

D) CORRECT:

The patient likely has mitral prosthetic-valve thrombosis. Patients with this complication of a mechanical mitral valve present with symptoms of heart failure or chest pain and physical examination findings consistent with left heart failure (e.g., tachycardia and pulmonary congestion). Cardiac auscultation usually reveals a reduced mechanical first heart sound, as well as systolic and diastolic murmurs in the mitral position. Inadequate anticoagulation can substantially increase the risk for mechanical-valve thrombosis. Oral contraceptives increase the risk for thromboembolism and may affect warfarin dosing.

Rapid assessment with cardiac imaging — such as an echocardiogram or direct visualization of the valve with fluoroscopy to establish the diagnosis of thrombosis of the mechanical valve — and consultation with cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery are imperative for a patient with suspected mechanical mitral-valve thrombosis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with a mechanical mitral valve who presents with respiratory failure, systolic and diastolic murmurs heard best at the apex, and a quiet mechanical heart sound is mechanical mitral-valve thrombosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Although atrial fibrillation with a poorly controlled ventricular response may be exacerbating the symptoms of a thrombosed mechanical mitral valve, it is not the primary cause of the patient’s symptoms. The presence of a subtherapeutic international normalized ratio, a reduced mechanical first heart sound, and systolic/diastolic murmurs in the mitral position raise concern for a mitral-valve complication as the primary abnormality.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the cardiology clinic to establish care. His medical history includes prior cocaine use, bacterial endocarditis, mechanical mitral-valve replacement 2 years ago, nonischemic cardiomyopathy, and hypertension. He is asymptomatic.
An echocardiogram one year ago showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 48% and a well-seated, normally functioning bileaflet mechanical mitral-valve prosthesis.
The patient has a regular heart rate at 82 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 100% while breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 8 cm. He has an audible mechanical click and no murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation. He has no lower-extremity edema.
His current medications are carvedilol 6.25 mg twice daily, losartan 50 mg daily, and warfarin 7.5 mg daily. His current international normalized ratio is 3.3.
Which one of the following medication changes, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reduce the warfarin dose to achieve a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3
Recommend one dose of amoxicillin each week for endocarditis prophylaxis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although guidelines previously recommended adding low-dose aspirin (75 to 100 mg per day) to warfarin therapy in this setting, this is now recommended only in patients who have another indication for antiplatelet therapy, such as coronary artery disease or cerebrovascular disease.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient does not have an ischemic cardiomyopathy or heart failure symptoms, so spironolactone therapy is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Warfarin therapy is indicated for all patients with mechanical valves to reduce the risk for thromboembolism, which is 1% to 2% yearly despite anticoagulation.

Although guidelines previously recommended adding low-dose aspirin (75 to 100 mg per day) to warfarin therapy in this setting, this is now recommended only in patients who have another indication for antiplatelet therapy, such as coronary artery disease or cerebrovascular disease.

The target international normalized ratio is typically 2.5 to 3.5 for patients with a mechanical mitral-valve prosthesis and 2 to 3 for patients with a mechanical aortic-valve prosthesis and no other risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, previous thromboembolism, or a hypercoagulable state).

Key learning point: All patients who have a mechanical heart valve should be treated with warfarin alone to prevent thromboembolism.

D) INCORRECT:

The target international normalized ratio is typically 2.5 to 3.5 for patients with a mechanical mitral-valve prosthesis and 2 to 3 for patients with a mechanical aortic-valve prosthesis and no other risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, previous thromboembolism, or a hypercoagulable state).

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended before certain dental procedures (e.g., those that involve manipulation of gingival tissue or the periapical region of teeth or perforation of the oral mucosa), open surgery, invasive respiratory tract procedures that involve incision or biopsy of the respiratory mucosa (e.g., tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy), procedures of the genitourinary tract with concomitant known colonization or infection, and procedures involving infected tissues. Weekly prophylaxis is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting 2 days of retrosternal chest pressure (7/10 on the pain index) and worsening exertional dyspnea, now occurring upon walking just a few feet. He also reports a nonproductive cough that is worse when he is supine. He reports no fevers.
His medical history includes a mechanical aortic-valve replacement for aortic stenosis 7 years ago for which he is taking warfarin, nonischemic cardiomyopathy (left ventricular ejection fraction, 39%), hypertension, and gout.
His heart rate is 126 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 87/52 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing 2 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 13 cm. His heart rhythm is irregularly irregular, and he has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur and a muffled mechanical second-heart-sound click. Both lungs have fine crackles at the bases. He has minimal lower-extremity edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatine kinase (U/liter)
346
60–400


Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme (ng/mL)
6
0–7


Troponin T (ng/mL) (4th-generation assay)
0.4
0–0.03


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
798
≤57


International normalized ratio
1.7
0.9–1.3


An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that the patient’s features and symptoms are not consistent with an acute aortic dissection, an aortogram is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism is not likely to result in congestive heart failure symptoms or signs, nor does it cause the mechanical aortic-valve click to be muffled on auscultation. Therefore, CT pulmonary angiography is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

The annual risk for mechanical-valve thrombosis is 0.3% to 1.3%, and it is even higher in patients whose anticoagulation is subtherapeutic. Thrombosis can impede prosthetic leaflet movement and lead to acute heart failure (present in this patient) and elevated serum biomarkers. Alternatively, embolism of the thrombus to the coronary arteries, brain, peripheral vasculature, kidneys, and other organs may occur.

Quickly diagnosing mechanical-valve thrombosis is critical. If it is not treated expeditiously, the thrombosis can progress to complete valve obstruction, resulting in cardiogenic shock and death. An echocardiogram or urgent cinefluoroscopy is useful for detecting the presence of thrombus and to assess mechanical-valve leaflet mobility.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of acute chest pain and symptoms of acute heart failure in a patient with a mechanical aortic valve and a subtherapeutic international normalized ratio is valve thrombosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient’s electrocardiogram does not show any ST-segment changes that suggest ischemia, so neither cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography nor adenosine radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging should take priority over assessment of the mechanical valve’s function.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient’s electrocardiogram does not show any ST-segment changes that suggest ischemia, so neither cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography nor adenosine radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging should take priority over assessment of the mechanical valve’s function.

questions.text: A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with fatigue and bilateral leg swelling. Her pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Her abdomen is distended with shifting dullness and tender hepatomegaly is present. Cardiovascular examination shows a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that increases in intensity with inspiration. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome is associated with bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and aortic dissection. Chronic and/or severe aortic valve disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. However, this patient presents with features of right heart failure. Left heart murmurs do not increase on inspiration, unlike the auscultatory findings in this patient. Moreover, other typical manifestations of Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, amenorrhea) are absent in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Acquired tricuspid valve regurgitation and signs of right-sided heart failure in a previously healthy patient suggest a diagnosis of tricuspid valve endocarditis, for which intravenous drug use (IVDU) is the strongest predisposing factor. The most commonly isolated pathogens in infective endocarditis due to IVDU are Staphylococcus aureus (most common), streptococci, and enterococci.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe vitamin B1 deficiency (usually secondary to alcohol use disorder in developed countries) results in wet beriberi, which typically manifests with high-output cardiac failure. While jugular venous distention, ascites, and peripheral edema are commonly seen in patients with high-output cardiac failure, other features such as dyspnea, tachypnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bounding peripheral pulses, a midsystolic murmur, and an S3 gallop would also be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is associated with aortic and valvular abnormalities of the left heart (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse). Chronic and/or severe left valvular heart disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. However, this patient presents with features of right heart failure. Left heart murmurs (except for mitral valve prolapse) do not increase on inspiration, unlike the murmur in this patient. Moreover, other typical features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., joint hypermobility, lens subluxation) are absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Untreated group A streptococcus pharyngitis can lead to rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which can manifest with heart failure in young or middle-aged individuals. However, as RHD mainly affects the valves of the left heart (i.e., the mitral and/or aortic valves), features of left heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bilateral basilar rales) would be expected and the intensity of the murmur would not increase on inspiration.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of right heart failure (jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly) and a murmur consistent with tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of difficulty breathing. He has had recurrent palpitations and several episodes of anxiety over the past 2 years, despite no change in his daily life. He has occasional sharp chest pain localized to the left upper sternal border. Two years ago, he had streptococcal pharyngitis, which was promptly treated with a 10-day course of penicillin. He has never traveled outside of the country. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3/6 holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex and radiates to the axilla with a mid-systolic click. Bilateral fine crackles are heard on lung auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ectopic production of serotonin occurs in carcinoid syndrome. In extraintestinal carcinoid tumors and carcinoid tumors that have metastasized to the liver, increased serotonin that bypasses hepatic first-pass metabolism and enters the right heart can lead to fibrotic degeneration of valves and, as a result, pulmonary valve or tricuspid valve disease (i.e., carcinoid heart disease). The left side of the heart (including the mitral valve) is very rarely affected because serotonin is broken down by pulmonary enzymes before entering the left atrium. This patient's murmur is best heard at the apex, which is not consistent with murmurs heard in right-sided valvular disease. Moreover, this patient lacks classic findings of carcinoid syndrome such as flushing, recurrent diarrhea, telangiectasia, and asthmatic wheezing.

B) CORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is caused by the accumulation of dermatan sulfate within the connective tissue of the mitral valve. In developed countries, it is the most common cause of mitral valve degeneration and subsequent mitral valve prolapse. As the disease course progresses, mitral regurgitation can occur. This patient presents with common features of mitral valve prolapse (palpitations, anxiety, chest pain, mid-systolic click). The new-onset dyspnea, holosystolic murmur, and crackles on lung auscultation are consistent with regurgitation of the mitral valve, indicating an advanced disease process.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification is a common degenerative process involving the mitral annulus that can, depending on the severity of calcification, result in mitral stenosis and/or regurgitation. However, in most cases, calcific valve degeneration is asymptomatic and only has a negligible influence on mitral valve function. It is the most common cause of aortic valve stenosis, not mitral valve regurgitation. Patients with aortic stenosis may present with exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris-like symptoms, and a systolic murmur. However, aortic valve stenosis often also manifests with exertional dizziness or syncope and causes a late systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates bilaterally to the carotids, not a holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the apex.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory valve degeneration occurs in rheumatic heart disease, a late sequela of group A streptococcal infection, which often affects the mitral valve. Earlier stages of rheumatic heart disease most often involve mitral valve regurgitation, which then later develops into mitral stenosis. The pathogenesis of the disease involves cross-reactivity with group A streptococci (also referred to as molecular mimicry), which results in the development of autoimmune antibodies. While this patient has a history of streptococcal pharyngitis, he was adequately treated with penicillin, which makes rheumatic heart disease unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive catecholamine release is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma. While patients with pheochromocytoma often have bouts of intense palpitations and elevated blood pressure, other common symptoms include pallor, throbbing headache, diaphoresis, and hypertensive crisis, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, pheochromocytoma would not account for this patient's dyspnea and holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla, and bilateral lung crackles on auscultation raise suspicion of pulmonary edema due to acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and exertional shortness of breath. He sometimes wakes up coughing and gasping for air. Two months ago, he emigrated from Bangladesh. He does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Auscultation of the lungs shows crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology.
