RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the office because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space that radiates to the carotids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman is planning a pregnancy. She has a history of rheumatic mitral stenosis requiring intermittent diuretic therapy. She denies chest pain but reports mild orthopnea. Physical examination reveals a prominent S1 and a soft diastolic murmur (see report).
Echocardiogram: Moderate pulmonary hypertension with an estimated right ventricular systolic pressure of 50 mmHg
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding potential complications from pregnancy?

choices.text: Emphasize substantial maternal risk and advise possible valvular intervention before pregnancy
Suggest adding prophylactic heparin throughout pregnancy without further intervention
Reassure that routine prenatal care alone is sufficient to minimize complications
Recommend continuing diuretics as the sole measure to ensure a safe pregnancy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mitral stenosis poses significant risks during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and heart rate, which exacerbate left atrial pressure and pulmonary congestion. Moderate pulmonary hypertension indicates elevated pulmonary arterial pressures, increasing the risk of right ventricular strain. Pre-pregnancy intervention, such as percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy, can relieve obstruction and reduce hemodynamic burden, minimizing maternal and fetal risks. Counseling should address these risks and the potential benefits of intervention.

Key learning point: Patients with mitral stenosis and pulmonary hypertension should be counseled about the significant risks of pregnancy, as it can exacerbate their condition and lead to serious complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic heparin is reserved for high thrombotic risk scenarios, such as atrial fibrillation or mechanical heart valves. In mitral stenosis with moderate pulmonary hypertension, the primary concern is hemodynamic stress, not thromboembolism. Heparin use without a clear indication can lead to bleeding risks and is not appropriate here.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine prenatal care is inadequate for patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis and moderate pulmonary hypertension. These conditions require specialized cardiac management and close monitoring to address potential hemodynamic changes and complications during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretics manage symptoms by reducing preload but do not address the underlying valvular obstruction or prevent complications like arrhythmias. Pregnancy increases blood volume and cardiac output, exacerbating mitral stenosis. A comprehensive management plan, including potential interventions, is necessary.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with decreasing exercise capacity over six months. He has a history of surgical correction for a congenital heart condition in childhood. Cardiac auscultation reveals a decrescendo diastolic sound best heard at the left upper sternal border, which becomes louder with inspiration. Jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated, and peripheral pulses are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis presents with a low-pitched diastolic rumble and an opening snap, best heard at the left lower sternal border or cardiac apex. The murmur's location and quality in this patient suggest a regurgitant lesion, not stenosis. Inspiratory accentuation aligns with right-sided pathology, but the overall profile does not support tricuspid stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis produces a diastolic rumbling murmur with an opening snap, best heard at the cardiac apex and accentuated by expiration. The murmur described here increases with inspiration and is heard at the left upper sternal border, indicating a right-sided lesion. Mitral stenosis is typically due to rheumatic heart disease, not congenital heart defect repair.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur along the left sternal border but does not typically vary with respiration. It is often associated with bounding pulses and a widened pulse pressure, which are absent here. The murmur's increase with inspiration suggests a right-sided heart issue, inconsistent with aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation is a common complication in patients with repaired tetralogy of Fallot, especially when a transannular patch is used. It manifests with a decrescendo diastolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border, which intensifies with inspiration due to increased venous return. Chronic volume overload from regurgitation can lead to right ventricular dilation and reduced exercise capacity, as indicated by mildly elevated jugular venous pressure. Routine echocardiographic monitoring is essential for detecting such complications and assessing right ventricular function in these patients.

Key learning point: A decrescendo diastolic murmur that increases with inspiration is indicative of pulmonary valve regurgitation, especially in patients with a history of Fallot tetralogy repair.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of palpitations. He reports feeling his heartbeat constantly in his chest. Over the past 3 weeks, he has developed shortness of breath on exertion. He denies chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at age 25. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left sternal border. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies. Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation due to valvular disease manifests with a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border (Erb point).
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 32-year-old woman who presents to the emergency department with fatigue and bilateral leg swelling. Her pulse is 92/min and respirations are 24/min. On examination, she has jugular venous distention and pitting edema of the lower extremities. Her abdomen is distended with shifting dullness, and there is tender hepatomegaly. Cardiovascular examination reveals a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration. Turner syndrome is associated with bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta, and aortic dissection. Chronic and/or severe aortic valve disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. However, this patient presents with features of right heart failure. Left heart murmurs do not increase on inspiration, unlike the auscultatory findings in this patient. Moreover, other typical manifestations of Turner syndrome (e.g., short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, amenorrhea) are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is associated with aortic and valvular abnormalities of the left heart (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse). Chronic and/or severe left valvular heart disease can lead to left heart failure, which typically manifests with dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and bilateral basilar rales. Acquired tricuspid valve regurgitation and signs of right-sided heart failure in a previously healthy patient suggest a diagnosis of tricuspid valve endocarditis, for which intravenous drug use (IVDU) is the strongest predisposing factor. The most commonly isolated pathogens in infective endocarditis due to IVDU are Staphylococcus aureus (most common), streptococci, and enterococci.

Key learning point: Intravenous drug use is the strongest risk factor for tricuspid valve endocarditis, which commonly presents with right-sided heart failure and a murmur that increases with inspiration.

E) INCORRECT:

Untreated group A streptococcus pharyngitis can lead to rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which can manifest with heart failure in young or middle-aged individuals. However, as RHD mainly affects the valves of the left heart (i.e., the mitral and/or aortic valves), features of left heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bilateral basilar rales) would be expected and the intensity of the murmur would not increase on inspiration.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of right heart failure (jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, ascites, hepatomegaly) and a murmur consistent with tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He reports occasionally waking up at night coughing and gasping for air. He emigrated from Bangladesh 2 months ago. He does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. On auscultation, there are crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination reveals a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology. RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

Key learning point: A high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, often due to rheumatic heart disease in individuals from developing countries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated from India 35 years ago. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. On examination, crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur, loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.

Key learning point: A water hammer pulse—rapid, forceful arterial upstroke followed by quick collapse—is a classic physical finding in chronic aortic regurgitation due to increased stroke volume and rapid runoff into the left ventricle.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to your clinic with increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has a history of hypertension and takes lisinopril. He has a 50-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, he has weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.

Key learning point: Aortic stenosis presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border radiating to the carotids, along with exertional dyspnea, dizziness, and weak peripheral pulses.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur at the right sternal border with radiation to the neck and a soft second heart sound. Which of the following is the most likely valvular abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation manifests with a diastolic murmur immediately following second heart sound, not the systolic murmur described in this patient. Echocardiographic findings include eccentric left ventricular hypertrophy and left ventricular dilation due to volume overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis produces a low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur, best heard at the heart apex. Echocardiographic findings include left atrial enlargement and a thickened, immobile mitral valve with reduced valve area.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur best heard at the heart apex with radiation to the left axilla. Echocardiographic findings include eccentric left ventricular hypertrophy and left ventricular dilation from volume overload.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation manifests as a holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration (Carvallo sign). Echocardiographic findings include right ventricular dilation and elevated right atrial pressures.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right sternal border with radiation to the neck and soft second heart sound are classic findings of aortic stenosis. Echocardiographic findings typically include thickened aortic valve leaflets, concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, and preserved ejection fraction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea over the past 2 months. She has a history of acute rheumatic fever in childhood. Physical examination shows an irregular pulse, a loud first heart sound with an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex and bilateral fine crackles. Echocardiography shows a mitral valve area of 1.2 cm2. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Elevated left ventricular filling pressures from diastolic dysfunction
Increased left atrial pressure from restricted mitral valve flow
Reduced left ventricular compliance from myocardial fibrosis
Decreased venous return from atrial fibrillation
Elevated pulmonary vascular resistance from chronic hypoxemia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated left ventricular filling pressures occur in diastolic dysfunction or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. In mitral stenosis, the left ventricle is underfilled due to impaired flow across the stenotic valve, leading to reduced rather than elevated left ventricular pressures.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Mitral stenosis mechanically obstructs blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole. This obstruction leads to elevated left atrial pressure, which is transmitted retrograde to the pulmonary veins and capillaries, causing pulmonary congestion, dyspnea, and orthopnea.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced left ventricular compliance from myocardial fibrosis occurs in conditions such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Mitral stenosis is a valvular disorder, not an intrinsic myocardial disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although atrial fibrillation commonly occurs in mitral stenosis and can worsen symptoms, decreased venous return is not the primary mechanism causing pulmonary congestion. The underlying mechanism in this patient is elevated left atrial pressure from valve obstruction, not arrhythmia.

E) INCORRECT:

While pulmonary hypertension can develop as a late complication of mitral stenosis, elevated pulmonary vascular resistance from chronic hypoxemia is not the primary mechanism. The pulmonary congestion is due to mechanical obstruction and elevated upstream pressures, not hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion that now occurs when climbing one flight of stairs. She reports one episode of dizziness while gardening last week. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. Physical examination shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space radiating to the neck, a weak and delayed carotid pulse, and soft second heart sound. Vital signs are BP, 150/85; P, 78; and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Increase lisinopril dose and outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing ACE inhibitor therapy alone is inappropriate for symptomatic aortic stenosis. While ACE inhibitors may be beneficial for cardiac remodeling, this patient requires urgent evaluation for potential valve replacement.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with the classic symptoms and signs of aortic stenosis including exertional dyspnea, dizziness, harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur radiating to the carotids, weak delayed pulse, and soft second heart sound. Echocardiography is the gold standard noninvasive test to confirm the diagnosis and determine stenosis severity. Symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis require cardiology consultation for potential aortic valve replacement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not routinely indicated for initial evaluation of aortic stenosis. Catheterization is only considered in symptomatic patients if noninvasive findings are inconclusive or inconsistent with symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Exercise stress testing is contraindicated in patients with severe symptomatic aortic stenosis due to the risk of precipitating dangerous arrhythmias or hemodynamic collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

While chest x-ray and BNP may provide supportive information, they are not the primary diagnostic tools needed for this patient.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with hypertension and diabetes presents with acute severe dyspnea and orthopnea. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 120; and oxygen saturation, 88% on room air. Physical examination shows bilateral fine crackles to the mid-lung fields and a holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating toward the axilla. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ACE inhibitors are beneficial in heart failure management, they are not the immediate priority in acute pulmonary edema. The patient first requires urgent treatment of volume overload and afterload reduction. ACE inhibitor therapy should be optimized once the patient is euvolemic and hemodynamically stable.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with acute mitral regurgitation and pulmonary edema. The holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation. The ECG shows sinus tachycardia. The combination of diuretics and vasodilators addresses both the volume overload and the pathophysiology of mitral regurgitation. Furosemide reduces preload and treats pulmonary edema, while nitroglycerin decreases afterload and improves forward cardiac output. This medical stabilization is the priority before definitive interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardioversion is indicated for unstable arrhythmias causing hemodynamic compromise. This patient's presentation is consistent with acute valvular disease rather than a primary arrhythmic cause. The ECG shows sinus tachycardia, and there is no evidence of atrial fibrillation or other arrhythmias requiring cardioversion.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization may be useful to evaluate for potential ischemic causes of acute mitral regurgitation, but it is not the immediate priority. The patient requires urgent medical stabilization of acute heart failure and pulmonary edema before invasive diagnostic procedures.

E) INCORRECT:

While surgical repair may be the definitive treatment for severe mitral regurgitation, immediate medical stabilization takes priority in the emergency department. Surgical consultation can be arranged after the patient is hemodynamically stable and the acute pulmonary edema is addressed.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of injection drug use presents with a 3-week history of fatigue, low-grade fever, and worsening dyspnea on exertion. Physical examination shows bilateral lower extremity edema and elevated jugular venous pressure. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that becomes more prominent with inspiration. What is the most likely underlying valvular pathology?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex with radiation to the left axilla. The murmur intensity typically does not increase with inspiration because venous return changes primarily affect right-sided cardiac structures.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis produces a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the carotids. This murmur does not typically change with respiration and is not holosystolic.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis produces a crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border. While right-sided murmurs may increase with inspiration, this condition manifests with an ejection-type murmur rather than a holosystolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis produces a diastolic murmur with opening snap best heard at the cardiac apex. The characteristic finding of mitral stenosis is a delayed diastolic murmur with decrescendo, not a holosystolic murmur. Additionally, respiratory variation is minimal in left-sided valve lesions.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Tricuspid regurgitation manifests as a holosystolic murmur best heard at the parasternal left sternal border. The pathognomonic finding is augmentation of the murmur with inspiration (Carvallo sign) due to increased venous return to the right ventricle. The patient's history of injection drug use and signs of right-sided heart failure support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 4-hour history of acute dyspnea and chest pain. She was discharged 6 days ago after treatment for ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Physical examination shows BP, 85/55; P, 110; bilateral pulmonary crackles; and a new holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex radiating to the axilla. Echocardiography shows severe acute mitral regurgitation with a flail leaflet. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Medical management with ACE inhibitors and beta blockers
Cardiothoracic surgery consult for mitral valve repair
Interventional cardiology consult for transcatheter mitral valve repair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medical management with ACE inhibitors and beta blockers is appropriate for chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) but inadequate for acute primary RM, which this patient most likely has. While heart failure medications may provide temporary symptom relief, they do not address the underlying structural problem and may worsen hypotension in hemodynamically unstable patients. Management of cardiogenic shock from acute MR typically involves careful administration of inotropes while expediting definitive treatment of the valvulopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous coronary intervention would be indicated for ongoing ischemia but does not address the acute mitral regurgitation from papillary muscle rupture. The structural damage has already occurred and requires surgical intervention rather than revascularization therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

An intra-aortic balloon pump serves as a bridging device for patients with acute mitral regurgitation whose symptoms continue to deteriorate despite medical therapy (e.g., with vasodilators and inotropes), but it is not the definitive treatment for the underlying structural valve problem.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- All patients with acute primary mitral regurgitation require urgent surgical repair or valve replacement. Papillary muscle rupture causing acute mitral regurgitation is a medical emergency that requires immediate cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery consultation. Medical therapy alone is insufficient and serves only as a temporizing measure while preparing for emergency surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter mitral valve repair is considered for patients with severe chronic mitral regurgitation who cannot undergo surgical repair. It is not the first-line treatment for acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with acute dyspnea and chest discomfort that began 2 hours ago while lifting boxes. Vital signs at presentation were BP, 75/40; P, 115; R, 32; oxygen saturation, 80% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse pulmonary crackles and a new soft, early systolic decrescendo murmur audible at the apex. High-flow oxygen is administered, and an IV norepinephrine infusion is started. Current vital signs are BP, 90/50; P, 105; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 94%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfer to the cardiac catheterization laboratory for immediate intervention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate intubation of hemodynamically unstable patients risks further cardiovascular collapse from sedation-induced vasodilation, loss of sympathetic tone, and positive pressure ventilation, reducing venous return. Pretreatment is recommended to optimize hemodynamics before attempting rapid sequence intubation in these patients. In addition, this patient's initial positive response to supplemental oxygen makes a potentially risky airway management procedure less appropriate than obtaining diagnostics to expedite definitive management of the most likely underlying cause of this patient's respiratory distress (i.e., acute mitral regurgitation).

B) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is invasive, often requires sedation, and is not appropriate as the initial echocardiographic assessment in an unstable patient with an unprotected airway. Less invasive approaches should be attempted first and are likely to diagnose this patient's suspected acute mitral regurgitation. Initial TEE may be appropriate in unstable patients with suspected aortic dissection; however, this patient's clinical presentation does not support this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Emergency bedside transthoracic echocardiography is the most appropriate next step. This allows immediate assessment of valvular function, the mechanism of mitral regurgitation, and cardiac function without delays or transport outside of a critical care setting. In acute mitral regurgitation with cardiogenic shock, rapid echocardiographic assessment is essential to determine the need for urgent surgical consultation and guide medical management. The choice between bedside formal echocardiography and focused cardiac ultrasound (FoCUS) depends on available resources, operator training, and protocols. FoCUS primarily helps assess cardiac contractility and rule out pericardial effusion, which are useful to guide initial hemodynamic assessment. It is generally limited in evaluating valvulopathies but can identify acute mitral regurgitation if color Doppler imaging is added to evaluate the area, volume, and direction of regurgitant jets. Formal echocardiography is nevertheless required for quantitative assessments to guide definitive therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Delaying cardiac assessment until complete hemodynamic stabilization may result in missing critical information needed to guide therapy in this patient with suspected acute mitral regurgitation. The underlying valvular pathology must be assessed to determine appropriate treatment strategies, including the need for urgent surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Transferring this patient with suspected acute mitral regurgitation to the cardiac catheterization laboratory without echocardiographic assessment is premature. The type and severity of valvular pathology must first be characterized to determine if catheter-based or surgical intervention is indicated.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with acute dyspnea and bilateral lower extremity edema. The patient has a history of severe mitral regurgitation but was previously asymptomatic. Vital signs are BP, 148/92; P, 108; R, 26; and oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension to 8 cm, bilateral inspiratory crackles to the mid-lung fields, and a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla. BNP is elevated at 1800 pg/mL. Which combination of medications should be administered first?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem are contraindicated in heart failure as they have negative inotropic effects and can worsen cardiac function. Morphine is no longer recommended in acute heart failure due to potential respiratory depression and adverse hemodynamic effects.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute decompensated heart failure secondary to severe mitral regurgitation with evidence of volume overload and congestion. IV furosemide provides rapid diuresis to reduce preload and alleviate pulmonary edema, while nitroglycerin reduces both preload and afterload through vasodilation. This combination addresses the fundamental pathophysiology of acute heart failure in valvular disease by reducing volume overload and improving forward flow. This patient's blood pressure is adequate to tolerate vasodilator therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Inotropic agents and vasopressors are reserved for patients with cardiogenic shock or severe hypotension. This patient has adequate blood pressure and no evidence of hypoperfusion or end-organ dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist with a slow onset that requires gradual dose titration, making it unsuitable for immediate symptom relief in acute decompensated heart failure. Digoxin is reserved for refractory symptoms in chronic heart failure and does not address the urgent need for rapid diuresis and preload reduction in acute management.

E) INCORRECT:

While these medications can be used to treat chronic heart failure, they are inappropriate for the initial treatment of acute decompensated heart failure. The immediate priority is addressing volume overload and congestion with diuretics and vasodilators. Beta blockers should only be started in beta-blocker-naive patients after hemodynamic stabilization, and ACE inhibitors are optimized as part of guideline-directed medical therapy once the patient has been stabilized.
